QuestionStem: Explore the photos to learn about some unicellular and multicellular organisms.

images.caption: E.coli bacteria are unicellular. They have whip-like structures that help them move and attach to host cells.
images.altText: This highly magnified image shows an oval-shaped E. coli bacterium.

images.caption: A protozoan is unicellular. This Amoeba proteus moves and engulfs prey by using extensions of its body.
images.altText: This highly magnified image shows a single, irregularly shaped cell.

images.caption: Oak trees are multicellular. They have many leaves to capture sunlight, and a specialized stem called a trunk.
images.altText: This photograph shows an oak tree with a tall trunk and many leaves.

images.caption: The Eurasian water shrew is multicellular. It uses its sensitive whiskers to hunt snails and aquatic insects underwater.
images.altText: This photograph shows a shrew, an animal with a size and body shape that is similar to a mouse.
